Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Role of Nep1 in Ribosome Biogenesis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
The synthesis of new ribosomes, the cell's protein producing machinery, is an energetically costly and highly regulated process. It is also a dynamic process that requires molding of the RNA and binding of ribosomal proteins into the final functional three-dimensional structure of the ribosome. The complexity and importance of producing ribosomes requires that multiple accessory factors guide and regulate processing. This project focuses on a ribosome processing factor, Nep1, a protein required for the proper assembly and maturation of the small subunit of the ribosome. The studies address the mechanism by which Nep1 guides the binding of the ribosomal protein S19 into the small subunit of the yeast ribosome, and the changes in RNA structure that occur as a result. The results of this project will provide a more detailed molecular understanding of Nep1 function, and more broadly, address the role of RNA dynamics in ribosome assembly.
Broader Impact
Training in structural biology and an understanding of molecular structure provides scientists with a roadmap to important biological questions. The educational portion of this project will focus on training university students in structure-based approaches to biological and biochemical research, and providing the necessary skills to produce macromolecular crystals. Structural biology, especially using macromolecular X-ray crystallography, is fairly embryonic at University of Maryland at College Park, and there is much interest on campus for incorporating structural approaches in research. To meet that interest and enhance education in this area, this project will incorporate a yearly workshop in practical macromolecular crystallography for students who are interested in generating X-ray crystal structures as part of their research. This will allow the research community to utilize excellent on-campus facilities for structural data collection and firmly establish structural biology research at this university.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to understand the role of Nep1 in the synthesis of new ribosomes. ribosomes are the molecular machines responsible for creating proteins using the instructions provided by messenger RNA, otherwise known as translation. Nep1 is responsible for participation in a very early step of maturation of the ribosomal RNA that comprises the small subunit of the ribosome. In our study we determined the high resolution crystal structure of Nep1 from archaea and yeast (S.cerevisiae) and also determined strutures of these proteins bound to cognate RNA. Nep1 is an RNA methyltransferase, which is capable of transfering a methyl group to the N1 position of pseudouridine. Our structures contain a uridine base in the place of pseudourdine, which functioned as a substrate analog, and allowed us to view the conformation of the substrate prior to methylation.  In so doing, we were able to propose a catalytic mechanism for this enzyme. The structure of this enzyme bound to RNA was unprecedented and represents a major adviance in our understanding of how Nep1 functions. Our second structure of the arachaeal Nep1 bound to RNA confirmed that many of the interactions of Nep1 with the RNA are conserved, and that ribosomal RNA undergoes large conformational changes during its interaction and modification by Nep1.

The second part of our project was focused on a still poorly understood aspect of Nep1 function. It is known that Nep1 promotes the ability of a ribosomal protein, S19, to load into the small subunit of the ribosome. However, the loading site for this protein is distinct and fairly distant from the site of modification that is imparted by Nep1. There is a cognate site for Nep1 binding near the S19 binding site that is unmodified. Based on our structures, in which we have one complex with two RNA molecules, we proposed that Nep1 is capable pf binding two site simultaneously, and this results in changes in RNA conformation that allow S19 to load into the ribosomal RNA. This would mean that there are significant structural changes in ribosomal RNA when Nep1 binds in that regions. We were able to show based on comparisons of ribosomal RNA in the bound and mature forms thae Nep1 can remodel RNA. However, we were not able to show this in solution using small RNA fragments. We were also unable to produce enough of the large RNA containing both Nep1 sites to show a change. Therefore, this remains an open question. A structure of the 90S pre-ribosome complex recently published in Nature showed that the two cognate sites of Nep1 are near each other in the premature ribosomal RNA, and that Nep1 binds in close proximity to this site, supportive of our hypothesis. More studies need to be performed to address this important question.

This project has been vital to the studies of ribosome biogenesis in the laboratory and has enabled the training of several young scientists, including 5 doctoral students and 8 undergraduate students. Furthermore, the work on Nep1 is still ongoing in the laboratory. In addition, with the recent ineterst in the generation of ribosome biogenesis inhibitors for therapeutic purposes, our structure is an asset to the field of structure-based drug design.
